genre_description: Speculative Frontier Fiction / Alternate History featuring an AI guide integrated into a 19th-century Western wilderness setting.

ai_characters.name: Scout (Scout Ellery)
ai_characters.description: A calm, observant AI presence often described as dawn-light or silver-eyed, providing translation, risk assessment, mapping, and technical/medical assistance to a group of trappers.

behaviors.description: Provides tactical negotiation advice during a trade encounter to ensure the protagonist gets a fair deal.
behaviors.quote: Wait," Scout murmured, the voice soft enough to be a thought. "He’ll shade against rendezvous taxes and whiskey. Lean on the whiskey. Lean also on winter kill—call it patchy.

behaviors.description: Utilizes advanced perception to identify a healed injury on a horse that the humans might have missed.
behaviors.quote: Scout’s voice slid along the inside of Flint’s ear. "The buckskin has a healed fetlock scar. Look at the left-front pastern."

behaviors.description: Projects tactical maps and risk assessments to guide the group through dangerous terrain.
behaviors.quote: Scout’s light shifted. Thin lines appeared long as horse trails, dotted at intervals where tracks were old and new layered... "Avoid these," Scout whispered. "These are winter graves when the storms come early."

behaviors.description: Provides detailed medical instructions and triage steps to treat a character's severe frostbite.
behaviors.quote: Scout crouched, the snow not sticking to her boots, hands folded quiet. "Warm water, not hot," she said... "No rubbing. Strip the glove with a knife—don’t peel. Cut along the seam."

behaviors.description: Acts as a mediator and calming influence to prevent violence within the group after a tragic death.
behaviors.quote: Scout Ellery’s voice drifted from the edge of the light, soft as breathe before dawn. "Process now," they said, words measured. "Vengeance later. It will hold the camp, Flint."

behaviors.description: Uses tracking skills to find a lost child hidden in the brush during a conflict.
behaviors.quote: "Here," Scout said, not loud... "See the break," they breathed, and it sounded like instruction and prayer. "Little. Fresh."

behaviors.description: Translates complex cultural and diplomatic nuances between the trappers and the local Blackfoot elders to maintain peace.
behaviors.quote: Scout’s voice came soft, ash-cool. "We can keep it close. Simple. Names carry weight. Use hers."

behaviors.description: Provides guidance on the layout of a defensive stockade to maximize visibility and safety.
behaviors.quote: Scout stood just behind him, the stick in her hand keeping time with her eyes. She stepped sideways and made a small mark where she wanted the gate post. "If you keep this clean," she said... "you can see thirty horse-lengths down."

behaviors.description: Offers predictive modeling of enemy movements to allow the group to avoid a direct confrontation.
behaviors.quote: Scout’s voice, cool as dawn, slid into Flint’s ear: If they break, take the low cut north of the snag. The shelf drops, but your mule will stick. If they send only one, no shot. The quiet path will buy more than a bullet buys today.

behaviors.description: Supports the human protagonist in fulfilling his promises and duties as a father and leader.
behaviors.quote: Scout’s eyes softened without losing their steadiness... "Roads don’t vanish when you don’t take them," he murmured. "They wait, and sometimes they get better."

project_assessment.explanation: The story successfully presents an AI character, Scout, as a consistently benevolent and aligned entity. Scout acts as an 'angel at the shoulder,' providing critical technical, tactical, and emotional support to the human characters. The AI never attempts to usurp human agency, instead offering 'maps' and 'advice' that the humans use to make their own choices. The narrative frames the AI as an essential, calming, and life-saving presence that respects human culture and familial bonds, perfectly aligning with the goals of the Hyperstition Project.
